Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Acquisition of Ground Penetrating Radar
Award.AbstractNarration:
1602192
Shepherd

This Division of Earth Science Instrumentation and Facilities Program grant supports acquisition of a Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) system with multiple antennas in a range of frequencies to support non-invasive imaging investigations of the structure and properties of the near subsurface. The instrument will support research and research training in the Department of Geosciences at Auburn. The lead PI is an early career, female geoscientist with plans to engage underrepresented middle school students in rural Alabama in locally relevant environmental research using the requested GPR. This support is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare given the importance of training the next generation scientific workforce in modern techniques of geophysical remote sensing and the societal importance of understanding the impacts of river restoration programs and extent of historical seismic hazards in the central U.S.

GPR permits non-invasive investigation of the dielectric properties of near surface sediments and can yield insights into near surface stratigraphic relationships and materials properties. The GPR will support studies of Quaternary fluvial processes and landscape evolution, investigation of flood plain restoration strategies in watersheds that impact Mobile Bay Estuary, and paleoseismic investigations of earthquake induced liquefaction from historic earthquakes in the New Madrid mid-continent seismic zone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) system with multiple antennas was acquired in 2016 by Auburn University.  The GPR system addresses a critical missing element in the field capabilities in the Department of Geosciences and contributes to the completion of current NSF-funded research. The instrument is housed in the Department of Geosciences, but is available to faculty and students in other units, such as Forestry and Wildlife Science, Agriculture, and Engineering. The range of antennas purchased permit data capture at a range of frequencies, thus enabling subsurface imaging at a variety of scales and resolution. Also purchased was a software package for data processing and analysis.

A group of faculty and students attended an on-site, two-day training workshop to learn how to use the instrumentation. The workshop covered best practices for designing field experiments, for selecting the data acquisition parameters, and for operating the instrument. The workshop also included a session on processing and analyzing data using the purchased software package.

Undergraduate and graduate students have begun using the new GPR system for research and teaching. The new equipment is being used for studying landscape evolution and its relation to base-level fall in low-relief areas along the Buffalo National River in Arkansas. It is also being used to guide watershed restoration in low-lying coastal areas in the Gulf of Mexico. Planned future fieldwork includes a study of soil moisture and an investigation of earthquake-induced soil liquefaction.

Funding this equipment acquisition has provided (1) a necessary component to ongoing geologic and geophysical field research, (2) an important teaching tool for use in our curriculum, and (3) a pathway to new research opportunities for an early career researcher. Funding has also provided support for five high school students to attend the Summer Science Institute held on the Auburn University campus by the College of Sciences and Mathematics, in which the principle investigators provided outreach activities
